Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: I balanced the package in my arms, double-checking the address. No one answered the door, so I snapped a photo for proof and set it gently on the mat, glancing at my phone. A flurry of messages from my activist group popped up: “Police are blocking exits! We need to coordinate—now!” My heart pounded. As a delivery person, I was expected to secure every package, confirm delivery, and move on to the next stop. But as an activist, I was responsible for the safety of my friends, for helping them stay calm and organized in the face of sudden danger. I could picture the crowd, the tension, the fear. My fingers hovered over my phone, torn between calling the customer to ensure their package was safe and jumping into the group chat to help guide people out. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each urgent in its own way. I stood frozen on the porch, caught between duty and conviction, the world waiting for me to choose.
